Kwoniella shivajii is a unicellular, eukaryotic organism that reproduces asexually through budding. It has a circular genome and lacks mitochondria, instead relying on an organelle called a hydrogenosome for energy production.

Phylogenetic analysis based on ribosomal RNA sequences has placed Kwoniella shivajii within the Tremellomycetes class of the phylum Basidiomycota. This class contains many species of yeasts that are known to be important in various biotechnological and environmental processes.

The species was named Kwoniella shivajii in honor of the prominent Indian scientist Shivaji, who made significant contributions to the understanding of microbial diversity in the region where the yeast was discovered.

Overall, Kwoniella shivajii represents a unique addition to the fungal diversity found in the Indian subcontinent and may possess interesting metabolic or physiological properties worthy of further scientific investigation.
